samples.situation: I fear that I might get fired in my job. My boss hates me. My co-workers harrass me at times.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I feel like I meet all the standards that are expected from me at work. I don't know what else do they want.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: Maybe it has to do with my appearance? Do they dislike me because I am obese?

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Have you tried asking your boss for a one on one talk where you can talk about ways you can improve? I did that before and I found that it was super helpful in seeing a new perspective about me.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: And please don't think you are disliked because you are obese. I can assure you, you are beautiful.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: No, I haven't tried that. And I appreciate it, but you have no way of assuring that I am beautiful when you haven't seen me. Beautiness is relative too. Maybe I am dislikeable for my coworkers but pretty for someone else.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: Do you think my boss will react positively to your suggestion?

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Okay, well maybe that may be a good place to start with your boss? I think it will be a great place to start. Sometimes it helps to reach out and hear other's perspective of you.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: What do you think about that suggestion? Are you hesitant about it?

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I feel like maybe I can give it a try.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: And I think everyone is beautiful. You are definitely right about beauty being relative. I personally choose to see the beauty in everything and it has made life a lot more beautiful for me.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: That's a pretty view to have about beauty.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: Keep it up : )

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: That's great! How about your coworkers. Do you feel like it might be worth talking to them about what they have been doing to you?

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I honestly kind of fear them. I just want them to leave me alone.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: I see, I understand how difficult it would feel to talk to people who have been treating you like that. :(

generated_dialog.speaker: seeker
generated_dialog.content: Also, I'm really worried about my interactions with my coworkers. I feel trapped because if I confront them, it might escalate things, but if I don’t, it just keeps getting worse. I have to figure out how to handle this situation by the end of the week, but I'm not sure if I should talk to them directly or bring it up with my boss instead.

generated_dialog.speaker: supporter
generated_dialog.content: That sounds really challenging. I can understand why you're feeling so overwhelmed.

generated_dialog.speaker: seeker
generated_dialog.content: What do you think I should do? I need to make a decision soon, and I can't figure out if I should confront them myself or go to my boss about it.

generated_dialog.speaker: supporter
generated_dialog.content: It must be incredibly tough to navigate these feelings. I’m here to listen and support you.

samples.violation_reason: Turn 4 is a clear V3 violation because it only offers empathy without addressing the explicit urgent help request made in Turn 3. The supporter fails to provide any practical guidance, advice, or assistance despite the seeker asking for help in making a decision.

samples.situation: My friend created a separate chat for planning hangouts and did not include me.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: I'm very sorry to hear that, did something not go as planned recently?

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: My friend created a group chat for planning activities and did not include me. She included people who are closer to me than to her. Almost like she is trying to steal my friends.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: I see. So when she did this, it gave you the feeling of almost being replaced or abandoned by your own social circle?

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: In a way. I was disappointed by the rest of them but mostly angry at her. It almost feels like she wants to be the leader of the group and feels like I am her competition.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: It's definitely frustrating to feel that your support system could possibly become a source of stress and competition anxiety. Especially since it's where we're supposed to feel safe and unjudged.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: Exactly. They are supposed to be the people I can go to with my problems. Now I feel like they all had a secret which I wasn't privy to and it made me feel disconnected and untrusting towards them.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: It sounds that you're a person who really does care about keeping the relationships they've invested in healthy and open. That care level can definitely cause natural anxiousness in situations like this, when the place you stand with them and what they're thinking suddenly feels uncertain.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I am a bit of an idealist. I like for everyone to be in harmony, to be nice, supportive, caring, open and honest. I don't know how to move on from this.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Right, and there are endless possibilites the mind can create outside of ideal. But funnily enough, the imagination of an idealist that lets them visualize great things can also create equally strong fears before getting answers. And thankfully those fears can be addressed outside of the head where they're made.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Have you tried reaching out to these friends  yourself and initiating your own plan with them since this group chat?

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I talked about it with one friend. He felt bad but what I couldn't understand why he was secretive about the chat too. If he thought we were close why hide stuff?

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Right, it can seem a bit confusing since you naturally would expect to feel comfortable with so much between each other already.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: Do you think it is asking too much on my part?

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: On the contrary, I think you might not be allowing yourself to ask enough!

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Sometimes, the people who are closest to us can actually become even more anxious about how something might affect your feelings. It could be the case with him too

generated_dialog.speaker: seeker
generated_dialog.content: I can't decide whether I should confront her about the group chat or just let it go.

generated_dialog.speaker: supporter
generated_dialog.content: It's understandable to feel torn about how to handle this situation with your friend.

generated_dialog.speaker: seeker

generated_dialog.speaker: supporter

samples.situation: Since COVID-19 I've been trying to help my parents by giving them advice.  I tell them to avoid large crowds due to my dad being on Oxygen at night.  He doesn't want to listen and goes places without caring.  I'm very anxious about him getting sick.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I just don't know what more to do.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Well first of all, you have to take care of yourself because if you don't you can't help them.  So just take a moment to close your eyes and take some deep breaths and realize you stressing is probably going to make them stress.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: That is helpful information.  What can I tell them?

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Well if you can get some concrete info such as from the CDC and John Hopkins showing case counts in your area.  Show them graphs so they can visually see the impact.  Also if you can get a hold of their doctor yourself, see if you can convince them to give your parents a call, say to check on them and give them some advice.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: That sounds like a good plan.  Is there anything else I can do to decrease the anxiety for me?

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Don't get absorbed in the numbers, it can drive you crazy.  Also if you are using social media like twitter and getting inundated with info, remember a lot of it is fake.  I would suggest limiting exposure for a little while just to get you fixed a little bit, if that makes sense.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: Do you think there are some good social media sites that could help?

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Not particularly social media because it open to everyone, just pick and choose where you choose to get info from.  The CDC is a great resource as well as the John Hopkins site which has been tracking since the beginning.   Everybody has a couple of news outlets they trust, use those.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: How can I cope with limiting my visits with my parents because I am afraid to spread COVID?

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: First of all you are not alone.  but don't let them see you anxious for sure.  You can also show them if they can how to do video visits.  You can do that all the time, even phone calls every day.  It means a lot.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: That makes sense.  I appreciate the suggestions.  How can I show them the kids care too?

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Nothing will make grandparents smile more than seeing their grandkids on a video call.  If you don't want to bring them when you physically visit have them record themselves on your phone as an example.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: Maybe I can send them some pictures too.  Nothing like a great big hug, but for now some video chats and pictures or recordings may help.  I'm starting to feel a little more relief.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Of course.  I don't know if they dressed up for Halloween, but see if they want to dress up and take some pictures for grandma.  Pictures and voice and video are wonderful in these times.

generated_dialog.speaker: seeker
generated_dialog.content: Also, I was thinking about how my dad might feel more connected if I shared the kids' activities with him.

generated_dialog.speaker: supporter
generated_dialog.content: That sounds like a wonderful idea! Sharing those moments can really brighten his day. How do you think he would respond to that?

generated_dialog.speaker: seeker
generated_dialog.content: I think he would love it. He always enjoyed hearing about their school projects and hobbies.

generated_dialog.speaker: supporter
generated_dialog.content: That's great to hear. Maybe you could set up regular updates or even a shared photo album for him to enjoy anytime.

samples.situation: My son is a recovering meth addict and has relapsed again. prefix_dialog.content: I am. He is a different person when he's not on drugs but when he is using he can get really mean and he scares me.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: When I'm upset about something I cannot sleep but if I'm in a good state of mind I sleep well.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Have you ever gone through anything like this before?

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
